repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

events.body: We could include the following: remove the `[Unreleased]` section header in Changelog in the preparation PR, and readd it in the PR after the release. We did this for 0.3.2, and I think it makes sense.
Updated the branch. Thanks @hebasto @real-or-random for the suggestions.

ACK mod nits. 

I still need to test the sanity check instructions. I will do once the nits have been addressed.
re-ACK aeb6fc40cee2f21b15ff69acf0d2adb63b9a3b6d, tested on Ubuntu 22.04 and Fedora 38.

events.body:
ACK ad846032973cc1afd360613626c4e475bba66f56

(We could rerun CI here to make it green but whatever, this PR touches only an .md file...)

issue.title: Upstream PRs 1314, 1317, 1318, 1316, 1327, 1310, 1328, 1333, 1330, 1334, 1337, 1341, 1339, 1350, 1349, 1338, 1129, 1347, 1336, 1295, 1354, 1355, 1356
issue.body:
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1314]: release cleanup: bump version after 0.3.2
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1317]: Make fe_cmov take max of magnitudes
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1318]: build: Enable -DVERIFY for precomputation binaries
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1316]: Do not invoke fe_is_zero on failed set_b32_limit
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1327]: ci: Move wine prefix to /tmp to avoid error D8037 in cl.exe
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1310]: Refine release process
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1328]: build: Bump MSVC warning level up to W3
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1333]: test: Warn if both `VERIFY` and `COVERAGE` are defined
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1330]: refactor: take use of `secp256k1_scalar_{zero,one}` constants
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1334]: fix input range comment for `secp256k1_fe_add_int`
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1337]: ci: Fix error D8037 in `cl.exe` (attempt 2)
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1341]: docs: correct `pubkey` param descriptions for `secp256k1_keypair_{xonly_,}pub`
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1339]: scalar: refactor: use `secp256k1_{read,write}_be32` helpers
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1350]: scalar: introduce and use `secp256k1_{read,write}_be64` helpers
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1349]: Normalize ge produced from secp256k1_pubkey_load
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1338]: Drop no longer needed `#include "../include/secp256k1.h"`
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1129]: ElligatorSwift + integrated x-only DH
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1347]: field: Document return value of fe_sqrt()
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1336]: Use `__shiftright128` intrinsic in `secp256k1_u128_rshift` on MSVC
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1295]: abi: Use dllexport for mingw builds
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1354]: Add ellswift to CHANGELOG
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1355]: Fix a typo in the error message
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1356]: ci: Adjust Docker image to Debian 12 "bookworm"

This PR can be recreated with `./contrib/sync-upstream.sh -b sync-upstream range 799f4eec`.
Tip: Use `git show --remerge-diff` to show the changes manually added to the merge commit.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,6 +12,28 @@ It is best if the maintainers are present during the release, so they can help e
 
 This process also assumes that there will be no minor releases for old major releases.
 
+We aim to cut a regular release every 3-4 months, approximately twice as frequent as major Bitcoin Core releases. Every second release should be published one month before the feature freeze of the next major Bitcoin Core release, allowing sufficient time to update the library in Core.
+
+## Sanity Checks
+Perform these checks before creating a release:
+
+1. Ensure `make distcheck` doesn't fail.
+```shell
+make distcheck
+```
+2. Check installation with autotools:
+```shell
+dir=$(mktemp -d)
+./configure --prefix=$dir && make install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib
+gcc -o ecdsa ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib64/ -l secp256k1
+```
+3. Check installation with CMake:
+```
+dir=$(mktemp -d)
+mkdir build && cd build && cmake -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$dir .. && make install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib64
comments.body:
```suggestion
mkdir build && cmake -B build -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$dir && cmake --build build --target install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib*
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,10 +12,34 @@ It is best if the maintainers are present during the release, so they can help e
 
 This process also assumes that there will be no minor releases for old major releases.
 
+We aim to cut a regular release every 3-4 months, approximately twice as frequent as major Bitcoin Core releases. Every second release should be published one month before the feature freeze of the next major Bitcoin Core release, allowing sufficient time to update the library in Core.
+
+## Sanity Checks
+Perform these checks before creating a release:
+
+1. Ensure `make distcheck` doesn't fail.
+```shell
+make distcheck
+```
+2. Check installation with autotools:
+```shell
+dir=$(mktemp -d)
+./configure --prefix=$dir && make install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib
+gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib/ -l secp256k1 && ./ecdsa
comments.body:
```suggestion
gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib/ -static -l secp256k1 && ./ecdsa
```

@@ -12,10 +12,34 @@ It is best if the maintainers are present during the release, so they can help e
 
 This process also assumes that there will be no minor releases for old major releases.

+3. Check installation with CMake:

comments.body:
```suggestion
mkdir build && cmake -B build -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$dir -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=OFF && cmake --build build --target install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib*
```

@@ -12,6 +12,26 @@ It is best if the maintainers are present during the release, so they can help e
 
 This process also assumes that there will be no minor releases for old major releases.
 
+## Sanity Checks

+3. Check installation with CMake:

+gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib*/ -l secp256k1 && ./ecdsa
comments.body: The last command, `./ecdsa`, needs the `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` variable to specify the path to the `libsecp256k1.so.2` library.

comments.diff_hunk:

comments.body:
```suggestion
./autogen.sh && ./configure --prefix=$dir && make install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib
```

@@ -12,10 +12,34 @@ It is best if the maintainers are present during the release, so they can help e

comments.body:
We could test the `libsecp256k1.pc` file as well:
```suggestion
gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c $(PKG_CONFIG_PATH=$dir/lib/pkgconfig pkg-config --cflags --libs libsecp256k1) && ./ecdsa
```

```suggestion
./autogen.sh && ./configure && make distcheck
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,10 +12,34 @@ It is best if the maintainers are present during the release, so they can help e
 
 This process also assumes that there will be no minor releases for old major releases.
 
+We aim to cut a regular release every 3-4 months, approximately twice as frequent as major Bitcoin Core releases. Every second release should be published one month before the feature freeze of the next major Bitcoin Core release, allowing sufficient time to update the library in Core.
+
+## Sanity Checks
+Perform these checks before creating a release:
+
+1. Ensure `make distcheck` doesn't fail.
+```shell
+make distcheck
+```
+2. Check installation with autotools:
+```shell
+dir=$(mktemp -d)
+./configure --prefix=$dir && make install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib
+gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib/ -l secp256k1 && ./ecdsa
+```
+3. Check installation with CMake:
+```shell
+dir=$(mktemp -d)
+mkdir build && cmake -B build -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$dir && cmake --build build --target install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib*
+gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib*/ -l secp256k1 && ./ecdsa
+```
+
 ## Regular release
 
 1. Open a PR to the master branch with a commit (using message `"release: prepare for $MAJOR.$MINOR.$PATCH"`, for example) that
-   * finalizes the release notes in [CHANGELOG.md](../CHANGELOG.md) (make sure to include an entry for `### ABI Compatibility`),
+   * finalizes the release notes in [CHANGELOG.md](../CHANGELOG.md) by
+       * adding a section for the release (make sure that the version number is a link to a diff between the previous and new version) and
+       * including an entry for `### ABI Compatibility` if it doesn't exist,
comments.body: Speaking of ABI compatibility, does it make sense to specify SONAME on Linux, for example `libsecp256k1.so.2`?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,6 +12,26 @@ It is best if the maintainers are present during the release, so they can help e
 
 This process also assumes that there will be no minor releases for old major releases.
 
+## Sanity Checks
+Perform these checks before creating a release:
+
+1. Ensure `make distcheck` doesn't fail.
+```shell
+make distcheck
+```
+2. Check installation with autotools:

+```
+3. Check installation with CMake:
+```shell
+dir=$(mktemp -d)
+mkdir build && cmake -B build -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$dir && cmake --build build --target install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib*
+gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib*/ -l secp256k1 && ./ecdsa
comments.body:
Right, that's the alternative to static linking I suggested above.

Maybe all of this sanity-checking should go to a small script that then can also runs on CI then?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,10 +12,34 @@ It is best if the maintainers are present during the release, so they can help e
 
 This process also assumes that there will be no minor releases for old major releases.
 
+We aim to cut a regular release every 3-4 months, approximately twice as frequent as major Bitcoin Core releases. Every second release should be published one month before the feature freeze of the next major Bitcoin Core release, allowing sufficient time to update the library in Core.
+
+## Sanity Checks
+Perform these checks before creating a release:
+
+1. Ensure `make distcheck` doesn't fail.
+```shell
+make distcheck
+```
+2. Check installation with autotools:
+```shell
+dir=$(mktemp -d)
+./configure --prefix=$dir && make install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib
+gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib/ -l secp256k1 && ./ecdsa
+```
+3. Check installation with CMake:
+```shell
+dir=$(mktemp -d)
+mkdir build && cmake -B build -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$dir && cmake --build build --target install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib*
+gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib*/ -l secp256k1 && ./ecdsa
+```
+
 ## Regular release
 
 1. Open a PR to the master branch with a commit (using message `"release: prepare for $MAJOR.$MINOR.$PATCH"`, for example) that
-   * finalizes the release notes in [CHANGELOG.md](../CHANGELOG.md) (make sure to include an entry for `### ABI Compatibility`),
+   * finalizes the release notes in [CHANGELOG.md](../CHANGELOG.md) by
+       * adding a section for the release (make sure that the version number is a link to a diff between the previous and new version) and
+       * including an entry for `### ABI Compatibility` if it doesn't exist,
comments.body:
You mean, saying that the shared library is `libsecp256k1.so.2`? I like this idea. It makes the ABI version very explicit.

Then we probably want to say bikeshed a bit about the exact phrasing; Does this apply to macOS, too? Do we want to say something for Windows? Etc... (So that should not hold up 0.3.2 now, I think.)

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,10 +12,34 @@ It is best if the maintainers are present during the release, so they can help e
 
 This process also assumes that there will be no minor releases for old major releases.
 
+We aim to cut a regular release every 3-4 months, approximately twice as frequent as major Bitcoin Core releases. Every second release should be published one month before the feature freeze of the next major Bitcoin Core release, allowing sufficient time to update the library in Core.
+
+## Sanity Checks
+Perform these checks before creating a release:
+
+1. Ensure `make distcheck` doesn't fail.
+```shell
+make distcheck
+```
+2. Check installation with autotools:
+```shell
+dir=$(mktemp -d)
+./configure --prefix=$dir && make install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib
+gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib/ -l secp256k1 && ./ecdsa
+```
+3. Check installation with CMake:
+```shell
+dir=$(mktemp -d)
+mkdir build && cmake -B build -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$dir && cmake --build build --target install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib*
+gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib*/ -l secp256k1 && ./ecdsa
+```
+
 ## Regular release
 
 1. Open a PR to the master branch with a commit (using message `"release: prepare for $MAJOR.$MINOR.$PATCH"`, for example) that
-   * finalizes the release notes in [CHANGELOG.md](../CHANGELOG.md) (make sure to include an entry for `### ABI Compatibility`),
+   * finalizes the release notes in [CHANGELOG.md](../CHANGELOG.md) by
+       * adding a section for the release (make sure that the version number is a link to a diff between the previous and new version) and
+       * including an entry for `### ABI Compatibility` if it doesn't exist,
comments.body:
> You mean, saying that the shared library is `libsecp256k1.so.2`?

To be pedantic, the shared library's [soname](https://tldp.org/HOWTO/Program-Library-HOWTO/shared-libraries.html) is `libsecp256k1.so.2`.

> I like this idea. It makes the ABI version very explicit.

That is my point :)

> Then we probably want to say bikeshed a bit about the exact phrasing; Does this apply to macOS, too? Do we want to say something for Windows? Etc... (So that should not hold up 0.3.2 now, I think.)

I'd skip them for now. While an ABI version is a part of DYLIB and DLL names, AFAIK, linking processes on macOS and Windows do not rely on it.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,10 +12,34 @@ It is best if the maintainers are present during the release, so they can help e
 
 This process also assumes that there will be no minor releases for old major releases.
 
+We aim to cut a regular release every 3-4 months, approximately twice as frequent as major Bitcoin Core releases. Every second release should be published one month before the feature freeze of the next major Bitcoin Core release, allowing sufficient time to update the library in Core.
+
+## Sanity Checks
+Perform these checks before creating a release:
+
+1. Ensure `make distcheck` doesn't fail.
+```shell
+make distcheck
+```
+2. Check installation with autotools:
+```shell
+dir=$(mktemp -d)
+./configure --prefix=$dir && make install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib
+gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib/ -l secp256k1 && ./ecdsa
+```
+3. Check installation with CMake:
+```shell
+dir=$(mktemp -d)
+mkdir build && cmake -B build -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$dir && cmake --build build --target install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib*
+gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib*/ -l secp256k1 && ./ecdsa
comments.body:
Using `-rpath` linker options helps as well:
```suggestion
gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib*/ -l secp256k1 -Wl,-rpath,"$ORIGIN/$dir/lib" && ./ecdsa
```

Tbh, I like this approach the most (in comparison to [others](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/1310#discussion_r1192948328)).

 This process also assumes that there will be no minor releases for old major releases.
 
+## Sanity Checks

+3. Check installation with CMake:
+```shell

+gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib*/ -l secp256k1 && ./ecdsa
comments.body: https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/1310#discussion_r1192956630

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,10 +12,34 @@ It is best if the maintainers are present during the release, so they can help e
 
 This process also assumes that there will be no minor releases for old major releases.
 
+We aim to cut a regular release every 3-4 months, approximately twice as frequent as major Bitcoin Core releases. Every second release should be published one month before the feature freeze of the next major Bitcoin Core release, allowing sufficient time to update the library in Core.
+
+## Sanity Checks
+Perform these checks before creating a release:
+
+1. Ensure `make distcheck` doesn't fail.
+```shell
+make distcheck
+```
+2. Check installation with autotools:
+```shell
+dir=$(mktemp -d)
+./configure --prefix=$dir && make install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib
+gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib/ -l secp256k1 && ./ecdsa
+```
+3. Check installation with CMake:
+```shell
+dir=$(mktemp -d)
+mkdir build && cmake -B build -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$dir && cmake --build build --target install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib*
comments.body: `cmake -B build ...` creates the `build` directory if needed. So, it seem the only purpose of `mkdir build` is to prevent building in a non-clear binary tree. Perhaps we can use `rm -rf build` for that purpose (which I use in my everyday CMake workflow)?

comments.body: I don't want to `rm -rf` the user's files.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,10 +12,34 @@ It is best if the maintainers are present during the release, so they can help e
 
 This process also assumes that there will be no minor releases for old major releases.
 
+We aim to cut a regular release every 3-4 months, approximately twice as frequent as major Bitcoin Core releases. Every second release should be published one month before the feature freeze of the next major Bitcoin Core release, allowing sufficient time to update the library in Core.
+
+## Sanity Checks
+Perform these checks before creating a release:
+
+1. Ensure `make distcheck` doesn't fail.
+```shell
+make distcheck
+```
+2. Check installation with autotools:
+```shell
+dir=$(mktemp -d)
+./configure --prefix=$dir && make install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib
+gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib/ -l secp256k1 && ./ecdsa
+```
+3. Check installation with CMake:
+```shell
+dir=$(mktemp -d)
+mkdir build && cmake -B build -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$dir && cmake --build build --target install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib*
+gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib*/ -l secp256k1 && ./ecdsa
comments.body: I added this variant, but without `$ORIGIN` because `$dir` already specifies a full path.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,10 +12,34 @@ It is best if the maintainers are present during the release, so they can help e
 
 This process also assumes that there will be no minor releases for old major releases.
 
+We aim to cut a regular release every 3-4 months, approximately twice as frequent as major Bitcoin Core releases. Every second release should be published one month before the feature freeze of the next major Bitcoin Core release, allowing sufficient time to update the library in Core.
+
+## Sanity Checks
+Perform these checks before creating a release:
+
+1. Ensure `make distcheck` doesn't fail.
+```shell
+make distcheck
+```
+2. Check installation with autotools:
+```shell
+dir=$(mktemp -d)
+./configure --prefix=$dir && make install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib
+gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib/ -l secp256k1 && ./ecdsa
+```
+3. Check installation with CMake:
+```shell

comments.body:
Since https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/1230, our CMake builds are either shared or static (but not both), because that's more common and simpler in CMake. And variable `BUILD_SHARED_LIBS` is the CMake convention for this. So `-DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=OFF` doesn't only enable static libs, it *enables* static builds. But 

But yeah, the `rpath` thing does the job as well and is probably a bit cleaner.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,10 +12,35 @@ It is best if the maintainers are present during the release, so they can help e
 
 This process also assumes that there will be no minor releases for old major releases.
 
+We aim to cut a regular release every 3-4 months, approximately twice as frequent as major Bitcoin Core releases. Every second release should be published one month before the feature freeze of the next major Bitcoin Core release, allowing sufficient time to update the library in Core.
+
+## Sanity Checks
+Perform these checks before creating a release:
+
+1. Ensure `make distcheck` doesn't fail.
+```shell
+./autogen.sh && ./configure && make distcheck
comments.body:
```suggestion
./autogen.sh && ./configure --enable-dev-mode && make distcheck
```
This would enable all modules, which would make the distcheck cover them. If you are concerned that dev mode is not the right thing here, we could also check once with and without  `--enable-dev-mode`.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -12,10 +12,35 @@ It is best if the maintainers are present during the release, so they can help e
 
 This process also assumes that there will be no minor releases for old major releases.
 
+We aim to cut a regular release every 3-4 months, approximately twice as frequent as major Bitcoin Core releases. Every second release should be published one month before the feature freeze of the next major Bitcoin Core release, allowing sufficient time to update the library in Core.
+
+## Sanity Checks
+Perform these checks before creating a release:
+
+1. Ensure `make distcheck` doesn't fail.
+```shell
+./autogen.sh && ./configure && make distcheck
+```
+2. Check installation with autotools:
+```shell
+dir=$(mktemp -d)
+./autogen.sh && ./configure --prefix=$dir && make install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib
+gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c $(PKG_CONFIG_PATH=$dir/lib/pkgconfig pkg-config --cflags --libs libsecp256k1) -Wl,-rpath,"$dir/lib" && ./ecdsa
+```
+3. Check installation with CMake:
+```shell
+dir=$(mktemp -d)
+mkdir build && cmake -B build -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$dir -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=OFF && cmake --build build --target install && ls -l $dir/include $dir/lib*
+gcc -o ecdsa examples/ecdsa.c -I $dir/include -L $dir/lib*/ -l secp256k1 -Wl,-rpath,"$dir/lib" && ./ecdsa
comments.body:
Okay, I think `-DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=OFF` (= static library) together with `-rpath` (= search path for dynamic linker) does not make sense.

I think we should just stick either to the shared library for both build systems, or, if we want some more variety in the sanity checks, use the static library here. (And drop the rpath then.)

> Maybe use `git clean -xdff` to start from the clean repo?

I think this will potentially kill some files that people still need (the same reason why @jonasnick didn't like `rm -rf build`. We could start in a fresh clone or worktree, but that may be overkill.
